note.p: Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.

Uriah Millsaps was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born in January 1828 in Copiah County, Mississippi, Millsaps attended schools in Indiana and Kentucky before becoming an attorney in Gallatin, Mississippi. He was appointed circuit court judge in Mississippi in the 1870s.
He was married to Sarah Ann Lewis and had at least six children that lived to adulthood. Millsaps died on January 9, 1897. He is buried in Hazlehurst Cemetery in Hazlehurst, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; The Times-Picayune, New Orleans, LA, January 13, 1897)

While the Mississippi Constitution grants each chamber some unique power, the House and Senate are equal partners in the legislative process as both chambers are required to enact legislation. Bills are originated in either house, and to become law, must receive a simple majority in both chambers. Once passed, it is sent to the Mississippi state governor for passage, veto, or pocket-veto, and the state legislature can overcome the veto with a two-thirds majority vote. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Legislation. Mississippi. Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi (1871)

gloss.p: The Mississippi Legislation Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi (1871) was passed by the state legislature to revise the state laws to be executed in 1871. Special commissioners J. A. P. Campbell, Amos R. Johnston, and Amos Lovering were appointed in 1870 to oversee changes to current laws by making amendments, creating new laws, or removing outdated statutes from the Mississippi law books. These amendments were produced for the legislature where they were further scrutinized and amended, eventually passing at the January session in 1871. (The Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi, 1871)

catDesc.term: Legislation. Mississippi. Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi (1871)--Section 108

gloss.p: Section 108 of Mississippi’s Revised Code of 1871 granted the governor authority to commute death penalty sentences within the state to imprisonment, and the power to issue pardons for other crimes and misdemeanors. All governor commutations and pardons were recorded in detail and presented to the state legislature each session. (The Revised Code of the Statute Laws of the State of Mississippi, 1871, 32–33)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

div.p: [note] 2/25/74 [/note]

STATE OF MISSISSIPPI,
EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT,
Jackson, Miss., [gap] 1873
To His Excellency A Ames Governor of Mississippi

Your petitioner would respectfully show, that at the August Term AD 1870 of the Circuit Court of Copiah County, State of Mississippi, he was indicted by the Grand Jury for an assault & battery, that he was arrested by the sheriff of said County, and entered into a recognizance for his appearance at the October Term AD 1872 of said Court to answer said charge, with A Andre as his surety in the sum of four hundred Dollars That in obediance to the conditions of said recognizance, your petitioner did appear before said Court, at said Term, when the District Attorney Mr A. J. McLaurin, upon consultation with R. P. Willing the former District Atty—under whose administration, the indictment was found, agreed to dismiss the case, and informed your petitioner that he could go home. Your petitioner supposing that an order would be made by the Court dismissing said indictment against him, and that he would not be re-quired to answer the same any further, gave the case no farther thought
At the succeeding Term of said Court

in consequence of a change in this Judicial District E H Stites Esqr acted as District Attorney. no steps was then taken in the case. But at the succeeding Term, it being the October Term A D 1873, T. E. Cooper Esq. in the absence both of McLaurin and Cooper Stites was appointed Dis-trict Attorney Pro Tem, and not being familiar with the cases on the Dock-et—took a forfeiture against your petitioner, and his security A Andre on said recognizance for four hundred Dollars. Your petitioner was under the impression that said case had been dismissed, or he would cer-tainly have appeared at Court, nor was he informed that said forfeiture had been taken, until after the adjourn-ment of Court, when it was too late to have it set aside. So well satisfied had your petitioner been, that said prosecution had been dismissed or would be, that he did not go to the expense of employing Counsel to look after said case. An execu-tion is now in the hands of the sheriff of said County, for the amount of said forfeiture, returnable the first day of April next. Your petitioner having no remedy in the Courts, to have

said forfeiture set aside, would respectfully ask your Excellency to remit the same, and refers your Ex-cellency, to the statement and recom-mendation of Mr T. E. Cooper who acted as District Atty when said for-feiture was taken, and to N U Mill-saps, the presiding judge, as well as that of R P Willing who was acting as District Attorney when said indict-ment was found
Respectfully
To His Excellency, A Ames Gov &c

I will state, that Mr Evans ap-peared at the Circuit Court, at the first Term to which his recognizance was returnable I suggested to Mr McLaurin that it would perhaps be to the interest of the state, to dismiss the case, as there would be some doubt about a conviction, and the of-fense amounting merely to an assault & Battery. I was under the impression that the case was to be dismissed and I am satisfied that Mr Evans so un-derstood it at the time. And if he had not ^been^ so impressed, he would have appeared at the Term of the Court, at which the for-feiture was taken, as he then resided in the Town of Crystal "Springs", only nine miles from the Court house. Mr E. is an orderly

law abiding citizen, and now Marshall of the Town of Crystal Springs, and I certainly think his case makes a strong appeal, for the ex-ercise of that power which is given to the Exec-utive in Sec 108 of the Code of 1871, to remit forfeitures
Respectfully
R P Willing

The forfeiture of the recognizance referred to in the above petition was entered up under my direction, at the Octr Term of the Circuit Court of Copiah County. I at that time was acting as Dist Atty Pro tem. The indictment had been filed for several terms and I have no doubt that had the Dist Atty been person-ally present the case would have been dismissed on the call of the Docket. My recollection of the case is that none of the Witnesses for the State were ever present at any time of the court—The forfeiture having been taken, on account of the absence of the defendant, which absence was caused by the promise of Mr Mc Laurin the Dist Atty to dismiss the case, it would be a great hardship to enforce the payment of the judgement. Mr. Evans, is a peacable law abiding citizen and I heartily join in the recommendation that the same be remitted by the Governor.
Very Respectfully,
Tim E Cooper
I do not believe Mr Evans would have failed to appear if he had not thought the case ^had^ already been disposed of. He would not neglect such a thing willfully

Uriah Millsaps
Judge &c

Answered,
February 25—1874

EXECUTIVE OFFICE,
STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.
